docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Doctors in the American Medical Association have, as you suggest (editorial, July 16), spoken out in favor of the patient protections offered by Senate Democrats in their patients' rights bill. Health maintenance organizations have far too much power. The great cost savings H.M.O.'s were supposed to produce are gradually disappearing.
docs.abstract: Letter from Dr Donald Holtzman, chairman of New Jersey delegation to American Medical Assn, on why doctors in AMA favor patient protections offered by Senate Democrats in their patients' rights bill; says that health maintenance organizations have far too much power and that great cost savings HMO's were supposed to produce are gradually disappearing

docs.lead_paragraph: Finally the New York State Legislature has resumed work on its budget, now 112 days late, with a $73 billion spending plan that was mapped out the old-fashioned way, behind closed doors. Last year's open negotiations were deemed a failure by the lawmakers after Gov. George Pataki, Zorro-like, slashed through much of the Legislature's early effort. Now, declaring that their process is more like Washington's, the Governor, Assembly Speaker and Senate majority leader have adopted a structure that cedes only small changes to 10 conference committees open to the public. The big three -- Mr. Pataki, Speaker Sheldon Silver and Joseph Bruno, the Senate majority leader -- have produced what was once called a gentlemen's agreement that the Governor will not shred this year's budget if the legislators stay within its $73 billion limit. The legislative leaders convened the 10 conference committees this week to figure out how to spend $1.1 billion on schools, health and other issues.
docs.abstract: Editorial criticizesd accord on New York State budget that was reached behind closed doors by Gov George Pataki, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and Sen Joseph Bruno; says it will allow public debate on only $1.1 billion of $73 billion plan
docs.snippet: Finally the New York State Legislature has resumed work on its budget, now 112 days late, with  a $73 billion spending plan that was mapped out the old-fashioned way, behind closed doors. Last year's open negotiations were deemed a failure by the...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Healtheon Corporation, which links doctors, insurers and patients through the Internet, said yesterday that it would provide on-line prescription services to customers of Merck & Company's pharmacy benefits unit. The unit, Merck-Medco, the largest American pharmaceutical benefit provider, will help pay for the development of an Internet-based service that will allow doctors to see a patient's medical history and the drugs available for treatment, Healtheon said. Shares of Healtheon rose $4.625, to $63.125, while shares of Merck fell $1.9375, to $68.6875.

headline.main: HEALTHEON TO PROVIDE ON-LINE PRESCRIPTIONS FOR MERCK

docs.abstract: Courtney Donovan letter says July 16 editorial on patients' right legislation did not mention that trial lawyers would have been rewarded handsomely if Democratic bill had passed, since it would have allowed patients to sue their health maintenance organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Seated in her wheelchair on a terrace at the university hospital, Wendy Scott gazed out at a thunderstorm that had blackened the noon skies and tried to explain why she had spent 12 years of her life traveling from one hospital to another in Britain and Europe, pretending to be ill so that she would be admitted as a patient. ''To begin with, it was just something I did when I needed someone to care about me,'' she said, speaking with the burr of her native Scotland. ''Then it became something I had to do. It was as if something took me over. I just had to be in hospital. I had to.''

headline.main: A Great Pretender Now Faces the Truth of Illness

docs.lead_paragraph: Following the lead of department stores, fast-food chains and now even private hospitals, the city's sprawling public hospital system has conducted its first-ever customer satisfaction survey. And some of what officials found surprised them: on the whole, patients expressed good feelings about city hospitals. Other things were not so surprising: a lot of patients thought doctors and nurses were too rushed and not very nice.

headline.main: City Hospitals' First Survey of Satisfaction Among Customers Finds It Unexpectedly High

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Bob Herbert (column, July 15) faults the managed-care industry for Donna McIlwaine's death. Yet her physicians did not give her complaints serious consideration and diagnosed an upper respiratory infection and ''panic attacks.'' Certainly those diagnoses would not have justified more extensive investigation. The doctors failed to realize the acuity of her illness and, as all too often happens, attributed her symptoms to hysteria. This is a well-recognized error on the part of doctors caring for women, as Mr. Herbert points out. This has nothing to do with managed care. IRENE N. SILLS, M.D. West Orange, N.J., July 15, 1999
docs.abstract: Dr Irene N Sills letter blames tendency of doctors to attribute women's symptoms to hysteria, not managed care, for death cited in Bob Herbert's July 15 column; drawing

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Health care should not be a business -- especially a ''for profit'' one (column, July 15). If I were Al Gore, I would throw caution to the wind and resurrect national health care. This time, however, the plan should be simplified, perhaps even modeled after Medicare.

docs.lead_paragraph: Politicians often like to say that they will not be slaves to public opinion. ''I don't run polls to tell me what to think,'' Gov. George W. Bush declares. That would be reassuring, except that Mr. Bush and others are harvesting campaign donations from special interests that expect to exert an influence more powerful than public opinion. Last week, Mr. Bush announced that his $37 million war chest was so big he would spurn Federal matching funds in the primaries and ignore campaign spending limits in effect since the 1970's. If he gets the nomination, Mr. Bush will almost certainly try to outdo President Clinton in raising vast sums of unregulated ''soft money'' for his party. This week, Senator John McCain plans to give the Senate a chance to remove the worst campaign abuses by bringing a soft-money ban up for debate. For decades, corporations and unions have been banned from donating to Federal candidates, and since 1974 there have been ceilings on donations by individuals and political-action committees. Mr. McCain's bill would extend these rules to money raised by the political parties, closing a loophole exploited by Mr. Clinton and Bob Dole in 1996.
docs.abstract: Editorial welcomes plans by Sen John McCain to bring legislation banning soft money in election campaigns up for Senate debate
